Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.

A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

For a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X] with deg f=n 
geq 0, the coefficient a_n is called the leading coefficient. If a_n=1, the polynomial is called monic.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
The unique smallest subfield $P$ of a field $K$, given by the intersection of all subfields in $K$, is referred to as the prime (sub)field in $K$.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A ring epimorphism is a specialization of a ring because it specifically refers to a type of ring homomorphism, which inherently operates within the structure of rings.
